joly.one: Marie Elisabeth Joly is born in Versailles to parents Thomas Joly, a hardware merchant in Paris, and Elisabeth Vivien, a dancer with the Comédie Française
joly.two: At the age of 7, Joly makes her first foray onto the stage of the Comédie Francaise in the role of Louison in Molière's Imaginary Invalid
joly.three: The Comédie Française permits an adult Joly to debut in an official capacity
joly.four: Joly refuses to participate in the day's performance and is replaced by Mademoiselle Olivier
joly.five: Amid controversy, Mademoiselle Joly is admitted the society of the Comédie Française
joly.six: Joly receives a raise following a complaint of added responsibilites and no compensation
joly.seven: Mademoiselle Joly is banned from participating in the troupe's administrative meetings
joly.eight: During the french revolution, Joly is imprisoned along with several other members of the company

bellecour.one: Jean-Claude-Gilles Colson, later known as Bellecour, is born
bellecour.two: Monsieur Bellecour is formally admitted to the Comédie Française
bellecour.three: Bellecour's request to retire is denied
bellecour.four: Due to his failing health, Bellecour frequently fails to attend administrative meetings
bellecour.five: Following an incident, Bellecour calms and defends his colleague Monsieur Raymond
bellecour.six: Monsieur Bellecour responds to a highly critical letter
bellecour.seven: Monsieur Lekain, Bellecour's colleague and dear friend, dies
bellecour.eight: Bellecour is tasked with the responsibility of investigating the possibility of the formation of second troupe to serve solely the royal court
bellecour.nine: Monsieur Bellecour reflects on his experiences at the Comédie-Française
bellecour.ten: Following the death of Monsieur Bellcour, Monsieur Préville writes to Monsieur La Harpe of the Mercure de France to protest the mean spritited eulogy that they had printed

contat.one: Louise Contat is born into a low class family
contat.two: Mademoiselle Contat officially debuts at the Comédie-Française
contat.three: Contat is formally recognized as a member of the troupe and receives a quarter share
contat.four: Contat is given a raise, bringing her to a half share
contat.five: Contat is given a raise, bringing her to three quarters of a share
contat.six: The adminstration debates the issue of maternity payment, with regards to Mademoiselle Contat
contat.seven: Contat receives a further raise, bringing her to a full share
contat.eight: During the french revolution, Contat is imprisoned along with several other members of the company
contat.nine: Mademoiselle Contat reflects frankly on her experiences with love
contat.ten: Following Contat's retirement, a performance of Othello is held in her benefit

mole.three: Molé debutes at the Comédie-Française, but is refused and returns to the provincial theatres
mole.four: Molé becomes a member of the Comédie-Française society
mole.five: With Lekain out sick, Molé creates the role of Hamlet
mole.six: Monsieur Molé creates the role of Romeo in 'Romeo and Juliette'
mole.seven: Molé and his wife are both severely ill
mole.eight: Molé misses an adminstrative meeting, giving the excuse that he has to relearn a role which he has completely forgotten
mole.nine: Molé takes Mademoiselle Candeille as a student
mole.ten: The other members of the troupe write to Molé to remind him that, despite his status within the company, he is still required to follow the rules set by the society
mole.eleven: Following the revolution, Molé returns to the theatre.
mole.twelve: Monsieur Molé and his family take a vacation
mole.thirteen: Already gone for too long, the troupe implore Molé to come back from his prolonged stay in the country

vpt.two: At the age of 6, Vanhove makes her first appearence at the Comédie-Française in the role of Joas is Racine's Athalie
vpt.three: Vanhove's reappearence as an adult is critally well received, her perfomances at court being particularly praised
vpt.four: Vanhove marries Petit, who is a violonist at the Comédie-Française
vpt.five: Madame Petit is formally admitted to the troupe as a double for Mademoiselle Olivier
vpt.six: An argument occurs between Olivier and her Daughter and Madame Petit over the distribution of rôles
vpt.seven: Much to the anger of Mademoiselle Fleury, Petit pulls rank in order to play the rôle of Iphéginie
vpt.eight: Vanhove marries infamous fellow actor François-Joseph Talma
vpt.nine: Madame Talma retires from the Comédie-Française
vpt.ten: Mademoiselle Vanhove becomes a countesse through her marrige to the Count of Chalot

preville.one: Pierre-Louis Du Bus, later known as Préville, is born
preville.two: From 1738 to 1753, Préville plies his trade in provincial theatres
preville.three: Monsieur Préville is formally admitted to the Comédie-Française
preville.four: Career on the rise, Préville's performances are critically well received
preville.five: Having gained significant status, Préville weighs in on the troupe's adminstrative decisions
preville.six: Préville copes with tha aftermath of a violent incident in Senlis
preville.seven: At the fervent request of his former colleagues, Préville comes out of retirement to return to the Comédie-Française
preville.eight: Following a long period of illness, Madame Préville passes away

troupe.one: The Comédie-Française moves to the 'Salle des Machines' in the Tuileries Palace

title.sub: From pint-sized prodigy to controversial character

six.caption: A word on the matter of pensions..

title.sub: The Don Juan of the wings
